item.title: Marvel Rivals’ Teased Venom Skin Opens a Pandora’s Box That It Can’t Close
item.description:
Marvel Rivals is going full steam ahead toward Season 3 now with its usual rollout of content announcements and streamer early access privileges. Marvel Rivals Season 3 launches on July 11, the same day that James Gunn’s Superman releases in theaters, and a lot of what it has to offer has now either been revealed in Dev Vision Vol. 07 by creator director Guangguang and lead combat designer Zhiyong, its season previews via content creators on Twitch, or other lore tidbits posted on X/Twitter.

It was because of content creator previews that players first saw confirmation of a black symbiote-suited Spider-Man for Marvel Rivals as a part of the Season 3 BattlePass, titled “Power of the Phoenix,” and that it accompanies an Evil Dance emote that references Tobey Maguire’s iconic dance sequence in Sam Raimi’s Spider-Man 3 . However, despite his presence seeming non-existent in terms of cosmetics so far, Venom has a massive role in this upcoming season’s lore and has had a costume teased that would not only be his most unique yet but also a potential game-changer for other characters’ skins in the future.

Separation Anxiety—There is No Venom Without Eddie Brock

Outside of voice lines shared between Venom and others as well as supplementary character lore, Marvel Rivals hasn’t necessarily gone out of its way to represent much about Eddie Brock, the host of the symbiote and Venom’s better or worse half, depending on who’s asked. This makes sense, though, as Eddie isn’t at all what’s interesting about Venom on paper, whereas the abilities he possesses, whether he’s depicted as parasitically or mutually bonded to the symbiote, are far more intriguing.

The second half of Venom’s biography, as it pertains to Marvel Rivals ’ original lore and Timestream Entanglement story, reads:

“While displaced in time and fighting in the occult wars, Venom glimpsed the horrific future awaiting this timeline. To prevent that future from happening, Venom knows he only has two options — kill the dark god Knull or imprison him on Klyntar and take his throne.”

Nonetheless, Eddie is an inseparable element of the character, and Season 3’s lore seems to be emphasizing that with a big role in the narrative and a skin that is unlike any Marvel Rivals costumes to date. Indeed, Eddie’s face being distinctly displayed in artwork for Venom’s second lore entry thumbnail and an upcoming Season 3 or 3.5 gallery card clearly suggests that a future skin will feature this unprecedented aesthetic.

What Venom’s Phoenix Force Skin Could Mean for Marvel Rivals

Marvel Rivals ’ so-called ‘Phoenix Force’ Venom skin would presumably have Eddie’s face exposed, emerging from the symbiote’s throat and wreathed in monstrous teeth. Despite being an iconic trope of Venom’s from other source material iterations, the reason why this would be exceptional in Marvel Rivals ’ costume catalog is twofold: firstly, Eddie’s face is now revealed in-game; and secondly, it opens the door to other creative costume choices based on a character being unmasked when they’re traditionally masked—or have their head swallowed by an alien organism, in Eddie’s case.

This won’t be the first time Marvel Rivals has unmasked an otherwise masked character, to be fair, as Peter Parker is seen unmasked in the MVP cinematic for the Bag-Man Beyond skin, and Black Panther has had multiple skins now where he’s unmasked. Regardless, Venom has only had skins so far that leaned on the symbiote and have been more or less creatively lacking, such as his Hyper Orange and Pink Bubble color swaps.

Of course, it’s possible that Eddie’s face being shown in ‘Phoenix Force’ may only be associated with an emote animation and not the skin itself, which could be disappointing if it’s not at least a toggleable skin change like Spider-Man’s Future Foundation costume turning black when the Identity Overhaul emote is inputted.

Venom’s melee animation elongating his head for a bite attack wouldn’t necessarily be an issue, either, if the symbiote could be animated to close its jaws over Eddie’s head. Plus, the full skin hasn’t even been revealed yet, and its mixture of symbiote and Phoenix themes will easily make it one of Venom’s most rare costumes, not unlike Ultron’s X-Tron skin. If Venom’s ‘Phoenix Force’ skin is any indication of how ingenious skins can be, Marvel Rivals ’ future content has the potential for truly stunning cosmetics.

item.title: The First New Zelda Game on Switch 2 Needs to Get One Thing Right That BotW, TotK Got Wrong
item.description:
The Legend of Zelda ’s debut on the newest Nintendo platform, the Nintendo Switch 2, has been a fairly quiet one. At launch, the only noteworthy releases in The Legend of Zelda franchise were Switch 2 Editions of the franchise’s wildly acclaimed Switch games, The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild and The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom . In the near future, the only Zelda game on the horizon is Hyrule Warriors: Age of Imprisonment , the third entry in the spin-off franchise that combines The Legend of Zelda and Dynasty Warriors .

Of course, Zelda fans are not starved for content with the franchise, as Tears of the Kingdom is only two years old, and the newest mainline entry, The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom , was released just last year. These recent releases may indicate that the next mainline entry in The Legend of Zelda franchise may still be a few years away. Still, the next game has one major area to improve upon from the franchise’s recent Switch titles.

The Legend Of Zelda On Switch 2 Has Room To Improve On BotW and TotK's Master Sword

The Legend Of Zelda’s Master Sword Has Been Nerfed As Of Late

When The Legend of Zelda is ready to go on the Switch 2, it needs to take a good look at the Master Sword. This sword is naturally Link’s signature weapon, and much of the franchise’s marketing and lore centers around it. In Breath of the Wild and Tears of the Kingdom , the Master Sword was notably optional, only being acquired by completing specific in-game quests, and its importance was also heavily downplayed in Echoes of Wisdom .

Despite being the franchise’s iconic weapon, the Master Sword was noticeably nerfed in Zelda ’s two 3D Switch entries. Its base attack stat is 30, and even though that number can increase when it enters its Awakened state, its maximum attack stat is still lower than several weapons in both titles. Furthermore, the Master Sword is beholden to the two games’ weapon durability system; while the sword itself doesn’t break, it does need to recharge between uses.

The Master Sword’s Importance To The Legend Of Zelda Should Be Noted

The Switch 2’s first major Zelda game should take the time to make the Master Sword a more powerful weapon. It has helped Link destroy evil forces time and time again, to the point where its nicknames include the Blade of Evil’s Bane and the Sword that Seals the Darkness. As a pivotal piece of Zelda ’s lore ever since its first appearance in The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past , Nintendo should increase the Master Sword’s damage output when the next Zelda game is ready to go.

While this could apply to more than just the Master Sword, the next Zelda game should also remove the durability system from the item. Weapon durability at large has been one of the biggest sticking points of Breath of the Wild and Tears of the Kingdom , so much so that the Switch 2 re-releases of these titles added a limited weapon repair item through the Zelda Notes feature on the Nintendo Switch app. While it was an interesting feature, the next Zelda game should ditch weapon durability entirely, especially with the Master Sword.

When The Legend of Zelda is ready to go on the Switch 2, it needs to take a good look at the Master Sword.

The Next Legend Of Zelda Could Give The Master Sword Greater Story Focus

One other thing that the next Zelda game on the Switch 2 can do is give the Master Sword an even greater story focus than it already has. Nintendo did a fantastic job integrating the Master Sword into the story of Tears of the Kingdom , but it’s rather odd that this sequence could be skipped entirely because the Master Sword is optional. Considering the weapon’s importance to Zelda as a whole, the next game should make the Master Sword a mandatory item once again.

The Legend of Zelda has seen the Blade of Evil’s Bane nerfed and downplayed across the last few titles. As the franchise’s most iconic weapon, it seems the weapon’s acquiescence to more experimental elements of new games has downplayed its importance to the series. When the next Zelda game arrives on the Switch 2, it should do everything to remind players of what made it so special in the first place.

item.title: Mecha BREAK: Aquila Tips And Tricks
item.description:
Each striker in Mecha BREAK comes with a steep learning curve. While learning the basic abilities of each mecha might seem easy, it could take a long time to master them. On top of learning the abilities of their own hero, players should also have some knowledge of other strikers.

Aquila is the master of long-range gunfights, thanks to its sniper rifle. The longer lock-on range allows this striker to keep a safe distance from enemies while dealing significant damage to them. Aquila is not a flawless striker, but it is a master of landing final blows.

Aquila's Weapon And Abilities in Mecha BREAK, Explained

Before talking about the abilities, let's have a quick look at Aquila's weapon. The Mobile Beam Cannon is a long-range sniper rifle that fires energy bullets. The weapon comes with two fire modes: hip fire and scoped fire. The latter deals over 80% more damage per shot compared to the former . Each fire mode uses a different magazine, but the hip fire requires a brief cooldown after each shot before the next bullet becomes available, and one of the firing modes requires charged firing.

The damage from a Mobile Beam Cannon is Direct Damage, meaning that part of the damage will directly target the enemy's HP, while the other part will deplete its shield.

Aux 1: Pulse Claw

When Pulse Claw is used, it throws a drone towards the locked-on target. If the target cannot dodge the drone, it will be immobilized , which simply prevents the target from moving or shooting. The immobilization time varies from 1 second to almost 2 seconds based on the mass of the target. Ultra-Heavy targets will only get immobilized for 1 second. Pulse Claw will also cause an interference, which disables the target's FCS for 2.5 seconds.

Since the drone doesn't move too fast, it's best to activate Pulse Claw when you are close enough to the enemy. This will also prevent the enemy from dodging the drone, as they won't have enough time to react. Even if the target is a melee striker, you shouldn't be scared of getting close, as the immobilization will give you enough time to move away and land a shot.

Aux 2: Airborne Kit

Enabling the Airborne Kit activates a secondary energy bar for Aquila and allows it to remain floating in the air. This is an exceptional ability for those looking to stand still while in the air and hunt down targets.

With the Airborne Kit, Aquila will have its energy tank doubled, which significantly helps with its mobility. While the ability is active, evading in the air will make Aquila untargetable for opponents, which is quite useful for repositioning after landing a few shots on the targets. It's also best to turn the Airborne Kit off after landing your shot. Reusing the ability only has a 1-second cooldown.

The major limitation of the Airborne Kit is its dedicated energy tank. So, the player must manage that energy carefully.

Aux 3: Multilock Radar

Using this ability, Aquila will get a significant boost to its lock-on range. Up to six targets can be locked on simultaneously , and the bullet-ready cooldown for the Mobile Beam Cannon will be significantly reduced.

The fire rate of the weapon will increase while Multilock Radar is active, but the weapon will only shoot each targeted striker once. Players can shoot each target once from hip fire and then once more from the scoped mode to get the most out of this ability.

Tips For Mastering Aquila in Mecha BREAK

The first thing that every Aquila player should learn is to keep a safe distance from brawler strikers like Welkin. Unless you have a Pulse Claw to use, getting up close with melee strikers is never a good idea, as Aquila doesn't have the tools to withstand the heavy damage coming from melee attacks.

The Aquila players should focus more on landing shots from distance and repositioning. This is the best way to be annoying with Aquila. At heart, Aquila is more of a support striker who excels at helping allies to kill their direct opponent. Aquila is most effective when the target is busy dealing with another ally . This will distract them from noticing the shots coming from Aquila and will reduce the necessity for you to reposition after each shot.

Another thing to avoid while playing Aquila is the targets that fly at high speeds. It's not necessary to try and avoid them completely, but you should try to prevent drawing their attention when they are not busy elsewhere. Strikers like Falcon or Skyraider can easily escape from Aquila's reticle , especially Falcon, which is totally untargetable while using its flying ability. So, when you draw the attention of a highly agile unit, they can easily maneuver around you and escape your shots, which puts the player in a completely vulnerable position.

Managing the energy bar is a crucial task while playing as Aquila. Simply put, running out of energy in the midst of a fight is quite dangerous for Aquila, and that's why using the Airborne Kit wisely can be a lifesaver most of the time.

Don't be shy about using Multilock Radar on single targets . Yes, they pay off better when multiple targets are in sight, but remember that the entire match period is not long enough to find more than a few opponents close together. So, if you feel like an enemy is only a few shots away from death, give it everything you have to hunt down the striker. Each kill will outnumber the enemy team for at least 15 seconds, and that's a big advantage in scoring points.

While using the scoped shot does deal a lot more damage, it's sometimes just not easy to stand away and hunt the enemies. Remember that Aquila is agile for some reason, and it can still be quite deadly by just moving and roaming above enemies and hitting them with hip fire shots. The scoped shots are powerful, but since they require manual targeting, there is a high chance of missing shots when firing in this mode. That's why hip fire is safer and more effective despite dealing less damage.

One last thing to remember when playing as Aquila is to always hunt down ground-focused strikers like Tricera or Stego if there are any on the enemy team. Both of these strikers become easy targets for Aquila when they switch to their stationary mode. Aquila players can easily lurk around above the head of their targets and land consecutive shots without even getting attacked by them. Since these strikers are used for holding an area, Aquila can break their defensive structure quickly and force them to leave the area.

Thanks to Aquila's direct damage, the extra shield from Stego or Tricera will not completely block the incoming damage. That's when the scoped firing mode proves its value, as the stationary targets are easy prey for Aquila's most dangerous shots.

While Stego and Tricera are the ideal targets for Aquila, other heavy strikers like Inferno or Hurricane are also too slow to react to an Aquila player. The only exception here is Narukami , which also favors standing still, but its stealth abilities help it to remain hidden from sigh. This can make it quite difficult for Aquila to locate Narukami before it's too late.

item.title: Persona 5 Phantom X All Romanceable Characters
item.description:
Those who want to unlock one of the Romance options of Persona 5: The Phantom X will need to work a lot and focus on upgrading their Social Stats, like Knowledge, Kindness, and Proficiency. Most of the characters that players can increase their Synergy Rank with are not available to become Soulmates, but some of them are.

This guide offers some insight on all Romanceable characters in Persona 5: The Phantom X along with all the requirements to romance each of them, all the exclusive rewards players can earn by reaching the Soulmate status, which gifts are better suited for each of them, and what places to visit in their outings.

All Romance Options In Persona 5: The Phantom X

The three characters available for romance in Persona 5: The Phantom X are Motoha Arai , Tomoko Noge , and Yaoling Li . Motoha is the first Persona user players meet besides Lufel, but strangely, it isn't until later in the game that she becomes a romance option. The same can be said about Tomoko , but Yaoling Li can become an early Romance option, and the Synergy Rank rewards she unlocks are quite good, so she's one of the best options if players are thinking about optimized gameplay.

There are only a few available romanceable characters in the current version of the game, but that might change in the future, so readers are advised to exercise discretion.

How To Romance Motoha Arai

To romance Motoha Arai, players need to complete the first Episode of the story and Kiuchi Palace and then complete the Side-Mission called ' The Day The Pearl Flies! .' After completing this Side Mission, the Batting Cages will become available, and a Synergy Bond with Motoha will be formed. Players need to reach a Synergy Rank of 15 to unlock the Romance option for Motoha (called Soulmates), and to manage that, they will need to increase their Proficiency Levels to at least 15.

Here's a list of the exclusive rewards that players unlock when Motoha becomes their Soulmate:

Rank 15

Soulmate Motoha Avatar

Rank 18

Work Out Emote

Rank 20

Strawberry Cream Frame

One of the things players can do to increase their Synergy Ranks with Motoha faster, is to give her gifts related to Sports. This is a full list of all the gifts that increase Synergy with Motoha the most:

  • Heart Ring - Found at the Jewelry Underground Market Store, requires 10 of Charm, and costs 88 K - Increases Synergy by 250 Points (125+125 for preferred first-time gift).
  • Alloy Baseball Bat - Found at the Supermarket in the Underground Market Shibuya, requires 13 Proficiency, costs 11 K - Increases Synergy by 52 (26+26 for preferred first-time gift).
  • GOAT Uniform - Found at the Supermarket in the Underground Market Shibuya, requires 10 Proficiency, costs 8600 - Increases Synergy by 44 (22+22 for first-time gift bonus).
  • Baseball Gloves - Found at the Supermarket in the Underground Market Shibuya, requires 5 Proficiency, costs 6900, can also be obtained at the Batting Cages for 1000 Coins - Increases Synergy by 34 (17+17 for preferred first-time gift).
  • Preserved Flower - Can be crafted on the Workbench - Increases Synergy by 26 (13+13 for preferred first-time gift).
  • Cat Hairpin - Found at the Accessory Shop in the Underground Market, Shibuya, costs 6900 - Increases Synergy by 20(10+10 for the preferred first-time gift).
  • Sports Towel - Found at the Supermarket in the Underground Market Shibuya, costs 3000, can also be obtained at the Batting Cages for 500 Coins - Increases Synergy by 16 (8+8 for preferred first-time gift).
  • Protective Sports Gear - Found at the Convenience Store in Central Street, costs 2800, can also be obtained at the Soccer Club Bulletin Store for 500 Coins - Increases Synergy by 14 (7+7 for preferred first-time gift).
  • Sumo Wrestler Stickers - Can be purchased in the Discount Store on Central Street, costs 1600 - Increases Synergy by 8 (4+4 for preferred first-time gift).
  • Gourmet Food Tour Guide - Can be purchased in the Convenience Store on Central Street, costs 700 - Increases Synergy by 8 (4+4 for preferred first-time gift).

Ideally, players would want to prioritize this Bond if they want to romance Motoha, and they can do so from the Synergy Rank tab in their Main Menu. Once they do so, they will be able to encounter Motoha more frequently. She prefers to meet Afterschool, so save those Action Points to go on outings with her.

How To Romance Yaoling Li

To romance Yaoling Li, players need to complete the first part of Episode 1 until the first Intermission. Then, complete the ' Foreign Exchange ' Side-Mission, where they will meet for the first time with Yaoling, and unlock her Synergy Bond. Yaoling is quite the foodie, and she will unlock tons of important crafting recipes for both the Workbench and the Cooking table. Players who want to romance her will need a high level of Knowledge to unlock all the meetings and opportunities to increase their Synergy Ranks.

Players can unlock these rewards once they manage to make Yaoling become their Soulmate:

Rank 15

Yaoling Soulmate Avatar

Rank 16

Overwhelmed Emote

Rank 20

Duck Hot Pot Frame

To increase Yaoling Synergy Rank faster, players should give her gifts related to Tourism, Technology, and Japanese culture. This list will help players pick the best gifts to give her during their outings, taking into consideration the highest value of Synergy Points first:

  • Digital Camera - Found at the Supermarket in the Underground Market Shibuya, costs 39,800 Yen - Increases Synergy by 128 (64 + 64for preferred first-time gift).
  • Paranormal VHS - Found at the Discount Store in Central Street, Shibuya, requires 10 Guts, costs 32 K - Increases Synergy by 110 (55 + 55 for preferred first-time gift).
  • Electric Tooth Brush - Bought from the Convenience Store in Central Street, Shibuya, costs 29,800 Yen - Increases Synergy by 104 (52 + 52 for preferred first-time gift).
  • Puzzle Rings - Bought from the Convenience Store in Shinjuku, Red-Light District, costs 4700 Yen - Increases Synergy by 24 (12 +12 for preferred first-time gift).
  • Japanese Sweets Sets - Bought from the Supermarket in Zoshigaya (Omotesando) for 3800 Yen - Increases Synergy by 20 (10 + 10 for preferred first-time gift).
  • Jasmine Tea - Can be crafted at the Workbench using Jasmine Leaves and Simple Envelope - Increases Synergy by 18 (9 + 9 for preferred first-time gift).
  • Black-Framed Glasses - Bought from the Discount Store in Central Street, Shibuya, costs 3560 Yen - Increases Synergy by 18 (9 + 9 for preferred first-time gift).
  • Idol Photo Set - Bought from the Convenience Store in Central Street, Shibuya, costs 3200 Yen - Increases Synergy by 16 (8 + 8 for preferred first-time gift).
  • Mixed Nuts - Bought from the Supermarket in Zoshigaya (Omotesando) for 2800 Yen - Increases Synergy by 14 (7 + 7 for preferred first-time gift).
  • Kendama - Bought from the Japanese Souvenir Store in the Underground Mall in Shibuya, costs 2400 Yen - Increases Synergy by 12 (6 + 6 for preferred first-time gift).

Yaoling Yi prefers to meet in the Evening, so check the City Life for activities marked with her face, or check the Phone Messages for any invitation from Yaoling. Players should also keep in mind that gifts lose effectiveness after the first use , so repeating gifts is not the best way to increase Synergy. Ideally, they should go from the cheapest to the most expensive of gifts, but always try to give something new on each 'date' to receive the ' first time ' boost.

How To Romance Tomoko Noge

Tomoko Noge is the third and final romance interest that the players can conquer in Persona 5: The Phantom X, and her Synergy Bond becomes available after the Sub-Mission Part-Time Dreamer has been completed. Tomoko prefers quiet places, sweets, and to work part-time, so most of her Synergy Rank rewards are related to boosting the Part-Time Jobs City Life activities. To unlock all Synergy Ranks with her, players need to have a high level of Kindness, so think about raising that stat before prioritizing her bond.

These are the exclusive rewards unlocked after Tomoko becomes a Soulmate:

Rank 15

Soulmate Tomoko Avatar

Rank 18

Whisper Emote

Rank 20

To You, With Love Frame

To boost Wonder's Synergy Rank with Tomoko, players should prioritize giving her gifts that are considered 'cute' and 'trendy,' as her Bio implies she likes those things. But to be more specific, here's a full list of Tomoko's preferred gifts:

  • Heart Ring - Found at the Jewelry Underground Market Store, requires 10 of Charm, and costs 88 K - Increases Synergy by 250 Points (125+125 for preferred first time gift).
  • Uji Matcha Flan Set - Bought from the Supermarket in Underground Market (Shibuya) for 12000 Yen, Requires Kindness Level 13 - Increases Synergy by 56 (28 + 28for preferred first-time gift).
  • Shichi-Kun Doll - Bought from the Convenience Store Central Street, Shibuya for 7800 Yen, can also be obtained from Shichi-Kun as a reward for his Quiz - Increases Synergy by 40 (20 + 20 for preferred first-time gift).
  • Super Loud Alarm Clock - Purchased from the Discount Store on Central Street, costs 7000 - Increases Synergy by 36 (18 + 18 for preferred first-time gift).
  • Choco Stick Value Pack - Bought from the Supermarket in Zoshigaya (Omotesando) for 4890 Yen, can also be obtained in Gift Pack rewards from visiting the Cinema at Shibuya - Increases Synergy by 24 (12 + 12 for preferred first-time gift).
  • Cat Hairpin - Found at the Accessory Shop in the Underground Market, Shibuya, costs 6900 - Increases Synergy by 20(10+10 for preferred first-time gift).
  • Sunflower Seeds - Can be crafted at the Workbench using Sunflower and Simple Envelope - Increases Synergy by 18 (9 + 9 for preferred first-time gift).
  • Strawberry Bento Box - Found in the Convenience Store in Shinjuku, Red-Light District, costs 3200 Yen - Increases Synergy by 16 (8 + 8 for preferred first-time gift).
  • Heart-shaped Hand Mirror - Found in the Jewelry Shop at Shinjuku, Red-Light District, costs 1200 Yen, can also be part of Gift Box rewards from Events - Increases Synergy by 6 (3 + 3 for preferred first-time gift).
  • Part-time Job Magazine - Bought from the Supermarket in Yogen-jaya, costs 800 Yen, also part of the random Gift rewards from Shichi-Kun Quiz City Life encounter - Increases Synergy by 4 (2 + 2 for preferred first-time gift).

Players can encounter Tomoko in the Afterschool hours, and attending her outings will most of the time involve helping her deal with new Part-time jobs. Tomoko is also a great romance target for players who want to make money fast, since she unlocks several boosts for Part-Time Job City Life activities.

item.title: Zenless Zone Zero Fans Can Get Up to 2000 Free Polychromes for a Limited Time
item.description:
Zenless Zone Zero players can claim up to 2,000 free Polychromes through the latest redeem codes and anniversary gift. Zenless Zone Zero recently shared details about its upcoming 2.1 update, which will bring new characters and several events.

HoYoverse's hit action RPG Zenless Zone Zero will soon wrap up Version 2.0, its most ambitious update to date. The patch not only kicked off Season 2 of the main story but also coincided with Zenless Zone Zero 's first anniversary. To commemorate the achievement, the developers gifted players a free S-Rank character and W-Engine of their choice and a ton of free pulls. Now, with the imminent release of Version 2.1, the game has unveiled even more exciting rewards, though only for a limited time.

Starting from July 4, 2025, Zenless Zone Zero players can receive up to 2,000 free Polychromes, 182,000 Denny, and various EXP materials. The rewards are meant to thank players for their support throughout the game's first year. The first redeem code comes from Zenless Zone Zero 's latest special program and gives players 300 Polychromes. Next, HoYoverse surprised fans across social media with five special codes, each rewarding 20 Polychromes. Finally, as an anniversary gift, all players will receive 1,600 Polychromes directly through their in-game mail. This adds up to 2,000 Polychromes, which equates to 12 free pulls. However, fans should keep in mind that redeem codes have an expiration date, and there's also a deadline for claiming the in-game benefit.

Zenless Zone Zero Codes and Limited Event Give Players 2,000 Polychromes

Redeem Codes

  • SPOOKSHACK (2.1 livestream) - 300 Polychromes, 30,000 Denny, 2x Senior Investigator Log, 3x W-Engine Energy Module
    • Expires on July 6 at 23:59 (UTC+8)

  • ZZZTHANK - 20 Polychromes, 30,000 Denny, 5x Senior Investigator Log
  • ZZZYOU - 20 Polychromes, 30,000 Denny, 5x W-Engine Energy Module
  • ZZZFOR - 20 Polychromes, 30,000 Denny, 5x Ether Plating Agent
  • ZZZSTAYING - 20 Polychromes, 30,000 Denny, 5x Bangboo System Widget
  • ZZZWITHUS - 20 Polychromes, 30,000 Denny, 5x Senior Investigator Log

In-game Mail Gift

  • 1,600 Polychromes
    • Claim between July 4 and September 3 at 23:59 (UTC +8)

The extra Polychromes could come in handy for players who are saving up for Zenless Zone Zero Version 2.1. The patch will add two new S-Rank Agents to the playable roster, Ukinami Yuzuha and Alice Thymefield. The fan-favorite units Hoshimi Miyabi and Tsukishiro Yanagi will also be rerunning. Version 2.1 is launching Chapter 2 of the main story, as well as a summer-themed flagship event. Zenless Zone Zero is also releasing beach skins for Alice, Yuzuha, Belle, and Wise. The latter two can be obtained for free through the main event.

Zenless Zone Zero Version 2.1 is scheduled to launch on July 16. The update will introduce players to a new faction, Spook Shack, which will play an important role in the next main story chapter. It will also set the stage for new explorable map areas like Sailume Bay and the Fantasy Resort. On the other hand, players have a final chance of pulling on Zenless Zone Zero 's current banners, which feature Caesar King's rerun and Ju Fufu's debut.

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL

Don't go into the Hollows.
I know, I know, there's Ether in the Hollows, bizarre creations, even heritage of the old civilization, all precious treasures. But don't forget, there's also spatial disorder, monsters and mutants running rampant, and ultimately, a disaster that could swallow the world. They are not a place where ordinary people should go.
So don't go into Hollows.
Or at least, don't go in alone.
If you insist on getting into danger, go to New Eridu first.
This city where the good and the bad mix has many people who need the Hollows: Powerful wealthy tycoons, gangs that stalk the streets, conspiracy nuts, and ruthless officials.
Make your preparations there, find strong allies, and most importantly—
Find a "Proxy".
Only they can guide people out of the maze-like Hollows.
Good luck!
